title: Ticket #5911: Invalid security session use by schedd
description:
CMS noticed many many p-slots that were unnecessarily idling. Investigation showed that negotiation was fine, but, when the schedd attempted to claim the p-slot, it unexpectedly had the socket closed by the remote end.

On the worker node, the corresponding lines were as follows: 

09/20/16 14:28:57 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#1, failing; this session was requested by SCHEDD <SCHEDDIP:4080?addrs=SCHEDDIP-4080+[--1]-4080&noUDP&sock=79603_edf1_35> on <SCHEDDIP:64714> with return address <SCHEDDIP:4080?addrs=SCHEDDIP-4080+[--1]-4080&noUDP&sock=79603_edf1_35>
09/20/16 14:28:57 (pid:5482) Failed to send DC_INVALIDATE_KEY to daemon at <SCHEDDIP:4080>: SECMAN:2009:DENIED authorization of server 'unauthenticated@unmapped/SCHEDDIP' (I am acting as the client): reason: CLIENT authorization policy contains no matching ALLOW entry for this request; identifiers used for this host: SCHEDDIP,SCHEDD.example.com, hostname size = 1, original ip address = SCHEDDIP.

Note that the timestamp in the session key is 1474378538, which is 09/20/16 13:35:38 (about the time the startd daemon started up).

Looking through the StartdLog, this was the first time the schedd had contacted this worker node.

It seems that the DC_INVALIDATE_KEY issue is a glideinWMS misconfiguration: should it even be possible for ALLOW_CLIENT to prevent session invalidation?

CMS uses the knobs that allow the secondary collectors to skip the forwarding of updates to the parent collector if it does not think the update is "significant": 

COLLECTOR_FORWARD_FILTERING = TRUE
COLLECTOR_FORWARD_INTERVAL = 600

Additionally, there were network connectivity issues throughout the day, but none logged between the startd startup and the error message at 14:28..

Current working theory is that "somehow" a private ad update is being missed, causing an invalid match-based session to be used for authentication. It's not clear how a public ad update would occur without a private ad update.
remarks:
2016-Sep-20 15:14:38 by bbockelm:
Possibly more mysterious: 

09/20/16 14:28:57 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#1, failing; .... SCHEDD <IP.236
09/20/16 16:19:26 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#32, failing; .... SCHEDD <IP.44
09/20/16 17:01:01 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#15, failing; ... SCHEDD <IP.227
09/20/16 17:06:01 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#22, failing; ... SCHEDD <IP.227
09/20/16 17:16:34 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#1, failing; ... SCHEDD <IP.47
09/20/16 17:26:40 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#15, failing; ... SCHEDD <IP.214
09/20/16 17:34:05 (pid:5482) DC_AUTHENTICATE: attempt to open invalid session <WORKERIP:33277>#1474378538#62, failing; ... SCHEDD <IP.214

Now, session IDs are supposed to be monotonically increasing and unique, no?

2016-Sep-20 15:29:55 by bbockelm:
Found the relevant code: newIdString in claim.cpp generates the new Claim ID and, indeed, the ID should be monotonically increasing. That means there are some bizarre and strange reuse issues going on here.

2016-Sep-20 15:42:35 by jfrey:
Update filtering within the collector tree may be contributing (#5913).

2016-Sep-20 15:47:08 by bbockelm:
I don't think it's the problem here, but it seems that the assumption the claim ID is unique is dicey. There's currently zero duplicated claim IDs, but 847 startds have identical IP addresses and startup times. It seems this is exacerbated by the fact glideins startup frequently and IPs are commonly reused (i.e., at Docker sites or same IP space between different clusters).

2016-Sep-20 16:01:45 by bbockelm:
Note that Claim ID #1 was used at13:50:29 by schedd IP *.51, then is attempted to be used again at 17:16:34 by schedd at IP *.47.

2016-Sep-20 21:11:43 by bbockelm:
There's no bizarre timeouts set. Here's what I see: 

REQUEST_CLAIM_TIMEOUT = 240
SEC_DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_TIMEOUT = 20
STARTD_CONTACT_TIMEOUT = 45

Not sure which of these apply here, but they all look much less than hours-long.

2016-Sep-21 11:29:30 by jfrey:
If two startds generate the same Claim ID and both end up going to the same schedd, then the two IDs will collide in the schedd's security session ID table. When the schedd attempts to use the second one, it will notice the collision and try to negotiate a new session with that startd. The following lines will appear in the log: 

SECMAN: failed to create session %s (key already exists).
SECMAN: existing session %s:
<session policy ad if D_SECURITY enabled>
SEC_ENABLE_MATCH_PASSWORD_AUTHENTICATION: failed to create security session for %s, so will try to obtain a new security session

2016-Sep-21 16:10:41 by bbockelm:
I see no instance of that message in the schedd logs.

2016-Sep-26 10:05:32 by bbockelm:
I do see a lot of these: 

09/26/16 17:01:02 (pid:11999) SECMAN: removing lingering non-negotiated security session <IP1:40031>#1474771235#107 because it conflicts with new request
09/26/16 17:01:02 (pid:11999) SECMAN: removing lingering non-negotiated security session <IP2:34784>#1474771651#172 because it conflicts with new request
09/26/16 17:01:02 (pid:11999) SECMAN: removing lingering non-negotiated security session <IP3:1853>#1474859376#92 because it conflicts with new request
09/26/16 17:01:02 (pid:11999) SECMAN: removing lingering non-negotiated security session <IP4:24618>#1474852573#52 because it conflicts with new request

Are they a similar issue?

2016-Sep-26 12:19:23 by bbockelm:
More oddities from the pool: the EventLog is very different from the schedd itself.

For example, the MATCH_EXP recorded in the event log don't match the MATCH_EXP recorded in the ClassAd: 

[root@HOST ~]# grep MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite `condor_q 36491.92 -af UserLog` | sort | uniq -c
     41     <a n="MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite">T2_DE_RWTH
     20     <a n="MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite">T2_ES_IFCA
      1     <a n="MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite">T3_US_OSG
[root@HOST ~]# condor_q 36491.92 -l | sort | grep MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite
JobAdInformationAttrs = "JobStatus,QDate,EnteredCurrentStatus,JobStartDate,DESIRED_Sites,ExtDESIRED_Sites,WMAgent_JobID,MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite"
MATCH_EXP_JOBGLIDEIN_CMSSite = "T2_US_Nebraska"

We're also seeing somewhere around 50% of our EventLogs missing the MATCH_EXP lines completely, even if the job is requesting it. Not sure if that's related.

2016-Sep-26 12:42:40 by bbockelm:
Whoops - just uploaded a misleading attachment (didn't realize schedd was at D_FULLDEBUG, meaning the particular message was expected)...

2016-Sep-27 15:49:06 by bbockelm:
NOTE: The above comment about the EventLog and MATCH_EXP_ is now understood to be completely separate and handled in a different ticket (#5921). So, for here, just ignore it.
creator: bbockelm
